content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.

Here is how you can solve this problem in Julia using DataFrames.jl package:

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    df = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df)
    df[:audi_a4_type] .= true
    return df
end
```
You can use this function like this:

```julia
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "toyota", "bmw", "audi", "volvo"], model=["a4", "corolla", "x1", "a4 quattro", "s60"])
new_df = audi_filter(df_cars)
display(new_df)
```
This will add a new column `audi_a4_type` to the DataFrame and set it equal to true only for rows where `manufacturer` is "audi" and `model` is "a4" or "a4 quattro".
